title: Meghan Markle Says She "Had No Idea" How Much Scrutiny She Would Face After Marrying Prince Harry
text:
From Town & Country

Prince Harry and Meghan have opened up about their struggles with the spotlight in some of the most candid interviews ever given by members of the royal family. The couple revealed their most personal thoughts in an hour-long documentary that was filmed throughout their 10-day tour of Africa last month and aired in the U.K. this evening. (It will premiere in the States later this week.)

Harry & Meghan: An Africa Journey was presented by Tom Bradby, a British news anchor who has known Harry for the best part of 20 years and whom the couple clearly felt comfortable speaking with.

He interviewed both Harry and Meghan several times as they traveled with son Archie through South Africa and Harry separately visited Botswana, Angola, and Malawi. While the tone of some of the earlier interviews was upbeat, by the end of the tour, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex had both spoken emotionally about their struggles, and Bradby admitted his documentary was “not always the one we expected.”

In a particularly frank interview in Angola, where Harry traveled to highlight Princess Diana’s work on landmines, Bradby asked the prince about whether he worried about his wife being under the same pressure his mother was. Harry replied, “I think you’ve probably slightly hit the nail on the head.”

“I will always protect my family and now I have a family to protect," Harry said.

“So everything that she [Diana] went through and what happened to her is incredibly raw every single day. And that’s got me being paranoid, that’s just me not wanting a repeat of the past.”

View photos Photo credit: Getty Images More

Bradby also asked Harry about his mental health, a topic that the prince has been open about previously. “I thought I was out of the woods and then suddenly it all came back. And I suddenly realized actually, no, this is something that I have to manage," he said.

“Part of this job, part of any job like everybody, means putting on a brave face and turning a cheek to a lot of this stuff. But again, for me and for my wife of course there’s a lot of stuff that hurts, especially when the majority of it’s untrue.”

He added, “I will not be bullied into playing a game that killed my mum.”

As the tour came to a close, it was revealed that Meghan is suing the Mail on Sunday for publishing parts of a letter to her father. A few days later, it was announced that Harry has filed claims against two tabloid newspaper groups for the alleged interception of voicemail messages. To many, especially at the end of a successful tour, it felt like the announcements came out of the blue. However, the documentary made it clear that anger over what they see as unfair treatment by sections of the media has been simmering for a long time.

When asked about what the last year has been like, Meghan told Bradby about the intense media scrutiny she has faced. “I had no idea, which probably sounds difficult to understand here. But when I first met my now husband, my friends were really happy because I was so happy. But my British friends said to me, ‘I’m sure he’s great. But you shouldn’t do it because the British tabloids will destroy your life,'" she said.

Meghan added that she "very naively" wondered what they were talking about. "So, it's been complicated," she said.

When asked it she could continue with things in the same way, Meghan replied, “I have said for a long time to H—that’s what I call him—It’s not enough to just survive something, right? That’s not the point of life. You’ve got to thrive, you’ve got to feel happy. I really tried to adopt this British sensibility of a stiff upper lip. I really tried."
description: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex give their most candid interviews yet in the new documentary Harry & Meghan: An Africa Journey.
